text: a warm welcome at the Kremlin today for
Alexis tsipras even while the EU locks
horns with Russia over Ukraine but does
this careful choreography carry an
implied threat that if the eurozone
won't be more lenient with Greece in its
hour of urgent financial need
perhaps there are others that might be
there is a long shared history between
Greece and Russia based in part on the
Orthodox faith more important perhaps
for people here in this old Athens
Church than for the confirmed atheist
who leads the Greek government but with
his country teetering on the brink in
Europe mr. tsipras is testing the
boundaries even if there may be limits
to what he can do even Moscow and
Beijing do realize that Greece is of
moral value if it is part of the
eurozone I don't see the Greek
government despite its difficult
financial situation ask him for a loan
from Russia one thing mr. tsipras would
like to achieve an easing of a damaging
Russian embargo on greek fruit exports
imposed as part of Moscow's response to
EU sanctions any kind of separate Greek
deal with Russia won't go down well in
Brussels or Berlin but in this Athens
market it's very good to open to finish
their burger and tower products to go to
Russia why to have a bar go we are not
enemies with Russia
so this visit to Moscow will be
presented here at home as evidence that
this is a government that does things
differently but elsewhere in Europe if
mr. tsipras is seem to be cozying up to
President Putin allowing him to play
divide and rule that will be regarded as
deeply unhelpful at a time when no one
can be quite sure where relations
between the EU and Russia are heading
Chris Morris BBC news Athens
